(JOURNAL)                MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 2003                        1
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “I have the honor to announce, on behalf of the Court, that the Octo-
ber 2002 Term of the Supreme Court of the United States is now
closed, and the October 2003 Term is now convened.
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified
and filed with the Clerk. They will not be otherwise announced.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 02–1553. Philip Morris USA Incorporated, Petitioner v. Mayola
Williams, Personal Representative of the Estate of Jesse D. Williams,
Deceased. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of
Oregon. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals of Oregon for further consider-
ation in light of State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company
v. Campbell, 538 U. S. ––– (2003).
   No. 02–1748. Chrysler Corporation, Petitioner v. Dorothy Clark. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light of State Farm Mu-
tual Automobile Insurance Company v. Campbell, 538 U. S. –––
(2003).
   No. 02–1752. Hughes Electronics Corporation, Inc., and DIRECTV,
Inc., Petitioners v. Robert Garcia, et al. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate Dis-
trict, for further consideration in light of Green Tree Financial Corpo-
ration v. Bazzle, 539 U. S. ––– (2003).
   No. 02–11173. John Marion Grant, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Okla-
homa. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma for further
consideration in light of Wiggins v. Smith, 539 U. S. ––– (2003).
JNL03$1006—11-02-03 20:53:34      JOURNAPGT           MILES




2                         MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 2003

   No. 03–54. Wien & Malkin LLP, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Helmsley-
Spear, Inc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Division,
Supreme Court of New York, First Judicial Department. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court
of New York, First Judicial Department, for further consideration in
light of Citizens Bank v. Alafabco, Inc., 539 U. S. ––– (2003) (per
curiam).

                      Orders in Pending Cases
   No. 02M96. William J. McCorkle, Petitioner v. United States. Re-
newed motion for leave to file a petition for writ of certiorari under
seal with redacted copies for the public record granted.
   No. 02M109. Roberto V. Arguelles, Petitioner v. Utah. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency
executed by petitioner granted.
   No. 03M1. M.K.B., Petitioner v. Warden, et al. Motion for leave to
file a petition for writ of certiorari under seal with redacted copies for
the public record granted.
   No. 03M2. Dean Alphonso Chambers, Petitioner v. John D. Ashcroft,
Attorney General, et al. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for
writ of certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. 03M3. Jeffrey L. Estep, Petitioner v. William F. Peace, et al.
Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-
time denied.
   No. 03M4. Thomas Freer-Heeter, Petitioner v. State Bar of Texas.
Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-
time denied.
   No. 03M5. Robert Goodson, Petitioner v. Larry Rowley, Super-
intendent, Northeast Correctional Center. Motion to direct the Clerk
to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. 03M6. Tommy Phillips, Petitioner v. M. Yarborough, Warden.
Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-
time denied.
   No. 03M7. Bill Guinn, Petitioner v. Susie McGuire. Motion to direct
the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time under Rule
14.5 denied.

of the Navy. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of
certiorari out-of-time denied.

4                        MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 2003

   No. 129, Original. Commonwealth of Virginia, Plaintiff v. State of
Maryland. Motion of plaintiff for judicial notice denied.
   No. 99–927. Wayne Anthony Ross, et al., Petitioners v. Alaska, et al.
Motion of petitioners for costs and attorney fees denied. Justice Breyer
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
   No. 02–428. Dastar Corporation, Petitioner v. Twentieth Century
Fox Film Corporation, et al. Motion of petitioner for attorney fees de-
nied without prejudice to filing in the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Justice Breyer took no part in the consideration
or decision of this motion.
   No. 02–626. South Florida Water Management District, Petitioner
v. Miccosukee Tribe of Indians, et al. Motion of National Hydropower
Association for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae granted.
   No. 02–811. Jeff Groh, Petitioner v. Joseph R. Ramirez, et al. Motion
of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument as
amicus curiae and for divided argument granted.
   No. 02–857. Household Credit Services, Inc. and MBNA America
Bank, N. A., Petitioners v. Sharon R. Pfennig. Motion of petitioners to
dispense with printing the joint appendix granted.
   No. 02–954. Office of Independent Counsel, Petitioner v. Allan J. Fav-
ish, et al. Motion of Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press,
et al., for leave to participate in oral argument as amici curiae and for
divided argument denied.
   No. 02–964. George H. Baldwin, Petitioner v. Michael Reese. Motion
of respondent for appointment of counsel granted. Dennis N. Balske,
Esquire, of Portland, Oregon, is appointed to serve as counsel for the
respondent in this case.
   No. 02–1019. Arizona, Petitioner v. Rodney Joseph Gant. Motion of
the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument as ami-
cus curiae and for divided argument granted.

granted.

in forma pauperis denied. Petitioner allowed until October 27, 2003,

Court. Justice Breyer took no part in the consideration or decision of
this motion.

                       Order in Pending Case
  No. 03–6821. David L. Nelson, Petitioner v. Donal Campbell, Com-
missioner, Alabama Department of Corrections, et al. Application for
stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Kennedy
and by him referred to the Court granted pending the disposition of
the petition for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for writ of certio-
rari be denied, this stay shall terminate automatically. In the event the
petition for writ of certiorari is granted, the stay shall terminate upon
the sending down of the judgment of this Court.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                        Orders in Pending Cases
   No. 03M22. George Sepulveda, Petitioner v. United States. Motion
to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time
denied.
   No. 03M23. Thomas Johnny Easton, Petitioner v. United States. Mo-
tion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-
time denied.
   No. 03M24. Michael Jennings, Petitioner v. Oregon Driver and Motor
Vehicle Services. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ
of certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. 03M25. Tyres F. Autrey, Petitioner v. Pascagoula Police Depart-
ment. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari
out-of-time denied.
   No. 02–271. Dow Chemical Company, et al., Petitioners v. Daniel
Raymond Stephenson, et al. Motion of respondents Joe Isaacson and
Phyllis Lisa Isaacson to retax costs granted. Justice Stevens took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
   No. 02–834. Jericol Mining Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Eugene Napier,
et al. Motion of respondent Eugene Napier for attorney’s fees denied
without prejudice to filing in the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit.
   No. 03–371. Republican Caucus of the Pennsylvania House of Repre-
sentatives, Petitioner v. Richard Vieth, et al. Motion of petitioner to
expedite consideration of the petition for writ of certiorari denied.

                         Certiorari Granted
  No. 02–1609. City of Littleton, Colorado, Petitioner v. Z. J. Gifts D-4,
L. L. C., a Limited Liability Company, dba Christal’s. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Cir-
cuit granted limited to the following Question: Whether the require-
JNL03$1014—10-07-04 13:16:27      JOURNAPGT          MILES




182                      TUESDAY, OCTOBER 14, 2003

ment of prompt judicial review imposed by FW/PBS, Inc. v. Dallas,
493 U. S. 215 (1990) entails a prompt judicial determination or a prompt
commencement of judicial proceedings.
   No. 02–1689. Grupo Dataflux, Petitioner v. Atlas Global Group, L.P.,
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit granted.
   No. 02–10038. Robert James Tennard, Petitioner v. Doug Dretke,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Correctional Institu-
tions Division. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted, and it is consolidated with
No. 02–11309, and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument in
these cases.
   No. 03–44. Basim Omar Sabri, Petitioner v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit granted.
   No. 03–218. John D. Ashcroft, Attorney General, Petitioner v. Amer-
ican Civil Liberties Union, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit granted.
   No. 02–1624. Elk Grove Unified School District and David W. Gor-
don, Petitioners v. Michael A. Newdow, et al. Motion of Pacific Legal
Foundation, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae granted.
Motion of Rutherford Institute for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted limited to the following Ques-
tions: 1. Whether respondent has standing to challenge as unconstitu-
tional a public school district policy that requires teachers to lead will-
ing students in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance. 2. Whether a public
school district policy that requires teachers to lead willing students in
reciting the Pledge of Allegiance, which includes the words “under
God,” violates the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment, as
applicable through the Fourteenth Amendment. The Solicitor General
is invited to file a brief in this case on behalf of the United States.
Justice Scalia took no part in the consideration or decision of these
motions and this petition.
   No. 02–1794. United States, Petitioner v. Manuel Flores-Montano.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit granted.
   No. 02–1824. Doug Dretke, Director, Texas Department of Criminal
Justice, Correctional Institutions Division, Petitioner v. Michael Wayne
JNL03$1014—11-03-03 12:26:22      JOURNAPGT          MILES




                         TUESDAY, OCTOBER 14, 2003                    183
Haley. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted.

   No. 03–5629. Garry Moore, Petitioner v. Mississippi. Motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi dismissed. See
Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s process,
the Clerk is directed not to accept any further petitions in noncriminal
matters from petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a)
is paid and petition submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin
v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per cu-
riam). Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.
   No. 03–5786. Aziz Safouane, et ux., Petitioners v. Washington De-
partment of Social and Health Services. Motion of petitioner for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of certiorari
to the Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 2, dismissed. See Rule
39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the
Clerk is directed not to accept any further petitions in noncriminal
matters from petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a)
JNL03$1014—11-03-03 12:26:22     JOURNAPGT          MILES




                        TUESDAY, OCTOBER 14, 2003                   203
is paid and petition submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin
v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per cu-

repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to
accept any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner
unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition
submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Co-
lumbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Ste-
vens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

(JOURNAL)                MONDAY, OCTOBER 20, 2003                   213
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas,
and Justice Ginsburg.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                        Opinion Per Curiam
  No. 02–1597. Michael Yarborough, Warden, et al., Petitioners v. Lio-
nel E. Gentry. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment reversed. Opinion per curiam.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 02–1019. Arizona, Petitioner v. Rodney Joseph Gant. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division Two. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals of Arizona, Divi-
sion Two, for reconsideration in light of State v. Dean, 76 P. 3d 429
(Ariz. 2003).

                     Orders in Pending Cases
  No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
Motion of the River Master for fees and reimbursement of expenses
granted, and the River Master is awarded a total of $3,351.04 for the
period April 1, 2003, through July 31, 2003, to be paid equally by the
parties.
  No. 126, Original. State of Kansas, Plaintiff v. State of Nebraska
and State of Colorado. Final Report of the Special Master received and
ordered filed.
  No. 02–458. Raymond B. Yates, M.D., P. C. Profit Sharing Plan, and
Raymond B. Yates, Trustee, Petitioners v. William T. Hendon, Trustee.

as amicus curiae and for divided argument granted.
  No. 02–1348. Olympic Airways, Petitioner v. Rubina Husain, Indi-
vidually, and as Personal Representative of the Estate of Abid M. Han-
son, Deceased, et al. Motion of Air Transport Association of America,

Inc., for leave to file a reply to brief amicus curiae of the United States

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                         Certiorari Denied
  No. 03–6728. John C. Smith, Petitioner v. Missouri. Application for
stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Thomas and
by him referred to the Court denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to

JNL03$1103—11-19-03 09:51:59      JOURNAPGT           MILES




(JOURNAL)                MONDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 2003                      237
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                         Opinion Per Curiam

   No. 02–1369. Betty Mitchell, Warden, Petitioner v. Gregory Esparza.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted. Judgment re-
versed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief Justice.

                      Orders in Pending Cases

  No. 03A202. Willie Taylor, Applicant v. Raymond Booker, Warden.

nor and referred to the Court denied.

tor, Oklahoma Department of Corrections, et al. Motion to direct the

General for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and

  No. 02–1371. Missouri, Petitioner v. Patrice Seibert. Motion of the

pauperis denied. Petitioner allowed until November 24, 2003, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33.1 of the Rules of this Court.

                          Certiorari Granted
   No. 03–101. Gale Norton, Secretary of the Interior, et al., Petitioners
v. Southern Utah Wilderness Alliance, et al. Petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit
granted.

for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit granted.
   No. 02–1845. Aetna Health Inc., fka Aetna U. S. Healthcare Inc. and

and
   No. 03–83. CIGNA HealthCare of Texas, Inc., dba CIGNA Corpora-
tion, Petitioner v. Ruby R. Calad, et al. Motion of American Association
of Health Care Plans, Inc., et al., for leave to file a brief as amici curiae
granted. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted. The cases are consolidated and
a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.

   No. 03–6134. Robert Hayden, Petitioner v. New York. Motion of

   No. 03–6138. Alvin Parker, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. Motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma dis-
missed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s
process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any further petitions in
noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the docketing fee required
by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in compliance with Rule
33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1
(1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases
cited therein.
   No. 03–6183. Byron E. Lee, Petitioner v. Jo Anne B. Barnhart, Com-
missioner of Social Security. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied. Justice Breyer
took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
   No. 03–6226. Michael Wayne Mason, Petitioner v. Superior Court of

in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the
Court of Appeal of California, Third Appellate District, dismissed. See
Rule 39.8.
   No. 03–6395. James Bernard Winke, Petitioner v. Old Republic
Surety Company, et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit dismissed. See
Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s process,
the Clerk is directed not to accept any further petitions in noncriminal
matters from petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a)
is paid and petition submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin
v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per cu-
riam). Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.
   No. 03–6689. Morris J. Perry, Sr., Petitioner v. R. L. Morrison, War-
den. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8.

                        Attorney Discipline
   No. D–2331. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard Stevens. Dis-
barment order entered.
   No. D–2355. In the Matter of Discipline of Albert J. Pirro, Jr. Albert
J. Pirro, Jr., of White Plains, New York, is suspended from the practice
of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–2356. In the Matter of Discipline of William Walter Frei-
hofer, Jr. William Walter Freihofer, Jr., of Longport, New Jersey, is
suspended from the practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue,
returnable within 40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

  No. 03–334. Shafiq Rasul, et al., Petitioners v. George W. Bush, Pres-
ident of the United States, et al.; and
  No. 03–343. Fawzi Khalid Abdullah Fahad Al Odah, et al., Petition-
ers v. United States, et al. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit granted
limited to the following Question: Whether United States courts lack
jurisdiction to consider challenges to the legality of the detention of
foreign nationals captured abroad in connection with hostilities and
incarcerated at the Guantanamo Bay Naval Base, Cuba. The cases are
consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice O’Connor, Justice Souter,
and Justice Thomas.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                   Appeal—Summary Disposition
  No. 03–411. Fred Parker, et al., Appellants v. Ohio, et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Southern District of
Ohio. Judgment affirmed.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 03–6200. Darick Demorris Walker, Petitioner v. William Page
True, Warden. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of Wiggins v. Smith,
539 U. S. ––– (2003).

peris without an affidavit of indigency executed by petitioner denied.

   No. 132, Original. State of Alabama, State of Florida, State of Ten-
nessee, Commonwealth of Virginia, and Southeast Interstate Low-
Level Radioactive Waste Management Commission, Plaintiffs v. State
of North Carolina. It is ordered that Bradford R. Clark, Esquire, of
Washington, D. C., be appointed as Special Master in this case with
authority to fix the time and conditions for the filing of additional
pleadings and to direct subsequent proceedings, and with authority to
summon witnesses, issue subpoenas, and take such evidence as may be
introduced and such as he may deem it necessary to call for. The Spe-
cial Master is directed to submit such Reports as he may deem appro-
priate. The compensation of the Special Master, the allowances to him,

the compensation paid to his legal, technical, stenographic, and clerical
assistants, the cost of printing his Reports, and all other proper ex-

borne by the parties in such proportion as the Court may hereafter
direct.

(JOURNAL)                MONDAY, DECEMBER 1, 2003                      319
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg and Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                      Orders in Pending Cases

  No. 03M30. Alfred Chaparro, Petitioner v. Gary Lindsey, Warden.
Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-
time denied.
  No. 03M31. John Jairo Duque, Petitioner v. Michael Yarborough,
Warden. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certio-
rari out-of-time denied.
  No. 03M32. Cory Richard Feres, Petitioner v. United States. Motion
for leave to file a petition for writ of certiorari under seal with redacted
copies for the public record granted.
   No. 03M33. Baosheng Zhou, Petitioner v. Pacific Medical Clinics. Mo-
tion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-
time denied.
  No. 03M34. Hector Vasquez-Hernandez, Petitioner v. Oregon. Motion
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indi-
gency executed by petitioner denied.
  No. 126, Original. State of Kansas, Plaintiff v. State of Nebraska
and State of Colorado. Motion of the Special Master for allowance of
fees and disbursements granted, and the Special Master is awarded a
total of $30,327.21 for the period April 16, 2003, through October 20,
2003, to be paid equally by the parties. Vincent McKusick, Esquire, of
Portland, Maine, the Special Master in this case is hereby discharged
with the thanks of the Court.
  No. 128, Original. State of Alaska, Plaintiff v. United States of
America. Motion of the Special Master for allowance of fees and reim-
bursement granted, and the Special Master is awarded a total of
$154,275.25 for the period April 17, 2003, through October 16, 2003, to
be paid equally by the parties.

writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California granted limited
to the following Question: Whether to establish a prima facie case
under Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U. S. 79 (1986), the objector must show
that it is more likely than not the other party’s peremptory challenges,
if unexplained, were based on impermissible group bias?

   No. 03–95. Pennsylvania State Police, Petitioner v. Nancy Drew Sud-

curiae granted. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit granted limited to the follow-
ing Question: Whether a complaint brought under 42 U. S. C. § 1983 by
a death-sentenced state prisoner, who seeks to stay his execution in
order to pursue a challenge to the procedures for carrying out the
execution, is properly recharacterized as a habeas corpus petition
under 28 U. S. C. § 2254?

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice

                               Opinions

  No. 02–749. Raytheon Company, Petitioner v. Joel Hernandez. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Thomas.
Justice Souter took no part in the decision of this case. Justice Breyer
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
  No. 02–473. United States, Petitioner v. Lashawn Lowell Banks. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed. Opinion by Justice Souter.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg and Justice Breyer.

                                Opinion
   No. 02–1674. Mitch McConnell, United States Senator, et al., Appel-
lants v. Federal Election Commission, et al.;
   No. 02–1675. National Rifle Association, et al., Appellants v. Federal
Election Commission, et al.;
   No. 02–1676. Federal Election Commission, et al., Appellants v.
Mitch McConnell, United States Senator, et al.;
   No. 02–1702. John McCain, United States Senator, et al., Appellants
v. Mitch McConnell, United States Senator, et al.;
   No. 02–1727. Republican National Committee, et al., Appellants v.
Federal Election Commission, et al.;
   No. 02–1733. National Right to Life Committee, Inc., et al., Appel-
lants v. Federal Election Commission, et al.;
   No. 02–1734. American Civil Liberties Union, Appellant v. Federal
Election Commission, et al.;
   No. 02–1740. Victoria Jackson Gray Adams, et al., Appellants v. Fed-
eral Election Commission, et al.;
   No. 02–1747. Ron Paul, United States Congressman, et al., Appel-
lants v. Federal Election Commission, et al.;
   No. 02–1753. California Democratic Party, et al., Appellants v. Fed-
eral Election Commission, et al.;
   No. 02–1755. American Federation of Labor and Congress of Indus-
trial Organizations, et al., Appellants v. Federal Election Commission,
et al.; and
   No. 02–1756. Chamber of Commerce of the United States, et al.,
Appellants v. Federal Election Commission, et al. Appeals from the
United States District Court for the District of Columbia. Judgment
affirmed in part and reversed in part announced by The Chief Justice.
Justice Stevens and Justice O’Connor delivered the opinion of the
Court with respect to the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act Titles I
and II, in which Justice Souter, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer
join. The Chief Justice delivered the opinion of the Court with respect
to the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act Titles III and IV, in which
Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, and Justice Souter
JNL03$1210—12-24-03 09:47:59    JOURNAPGT            MILES




388                   WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 10, 2003

join, in which Justice Stevens, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer
join except with respect to the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act § 305,
and in which Justice Thomas joins with respect to the Bipartisan Cam-
paign Reform Act §§ 304, 305, 307, 316, 319, and 403(b). Justice Breyer
delivered the opinion of the Court with respect to Bipartisan Campaign
Reform Act Title V, in which Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor, Justice
Souter, and Justice Ginsburg join. Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia
with respect to the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act Titles III and
IV, dissenting with respect to the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act
Titles I and V, and concurring in the judgment in part and dissenting
in part with respect to the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act Title II.
Concurring opinion by Justice Thomas with respect to the Bipartisan
Campaign Reform Act Titles III and IV, except for the Bipartisan
Campaign Reform Act §§ 311 and 318, concurring in the result with
respect to the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act § 318, concurring in
the judgment in part and dissenting in part with respect to the Biparti-
san Campaign Reform Act Title II, and dissenting with respect to the
Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act Titles I, V, and § 311, in which Justice
Scalia joins as to Parts I, II-A, and II-B. Opinion by Justice Kennedy
concurring in the judgment in part and dissenting in part with respect
to the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act Titles I and II, in which The
Chief Justice joins, in which Justice Scalia joins except to the extent
the opinion upholds new Federal Election Campaign Act § 323(e) and
Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act § 202, and in which Justice Thomas
joins with respect to Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act § 213. Dissent-
ing opinion by The Chief Justice with respect to the Bipartisan Cam-
paign Reform Act Titles I and V, in which Justice Scalia and Justice
Kennedy join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with respect to
Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act § 305, in which Justice Ginsburg and
Justice Breyer join.

                       Attorney Discipline

  No. D–2357. In the Matter of Discipline of Robert R. Wightman.
Robert R. Wightman, of Dallas, Texas, is suspended from the practice
of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.
  No. D–2358. In the Matter of Discipline of Charles W. Blackwell.
Charles W. Blackwell, of Rock Hill, South Carolina, is suspended from
the practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable
within 40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

(JOURNAL)               TUESDAY, JANUARY 13, 2004                  479
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg and Justice Breyer.

                               Opinions

  No. 02–1060. Illinois, Petitioner v. Robert S. Lidster. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois. Judgment reversed. Opin-
ion by Justice Breyer. Opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice
Souter and Justice Ginsburg join concurring in part and dissenting
in part.
   No. 02–682. Verizon Communications Inc., Petitioner v. Law Offices
of Curtis V. Trinko, LLP. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Scalia. Opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Jus-
tice Souter and Justice Thomas join concurring in the judgment.
  No. 02–1196. Securities and Exchange Commission, Petitioner v.
Charles E. Edwards. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice O’Connor.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice

  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                Certiorari—Summary Dispositions
   No. 02–1423. BellSouth Corporation and BellSouth Telecommunica-
tions, Inc., Petitioners v. Covad Communications Company, et al. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of Verizon
Communications Inc. v. Law Offices of Curtis V. Trinko, LLP, 540
U. S. ––– (2004).
   No. 03–241. Qwest Corporation, Petitioner v. MetroNet Services
Corporation. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in
light of Verizon Communications Inc. v. Law Offices of Curtis V.
Trinko, LLP, 540 U. S. ––– (2004).

(JOURNAL)              TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 2004                   613
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

     Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Con-
nor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas,
Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                               Opinions

  No. 02–8286. Delma Banks, Jr., Petitioner v. Doug Dretke, Director,
Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Correctional Institutions Divi-
sion. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg.
Opinion by Justice Thomas, with whom Justice Scalia joins, concurring
in part and dissenting in part.
  No. 02–1348. Olympic Airways, Petitioner v. Rubina Husain, Indi-
vidually, and as Personal Representative of the Estate of Abid M. Han-
son, Deceased, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Thomas. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice
O’Connor joins as to Parts I and II. Justice Breyer took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
   No. 02–1080. General Dynamics Land Systems, Inc., Petitioner v.
Dennis Cline, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed. Opinion by Justice
Souter. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Thomas, with whom Justice Kennedy joins.
  No. 02–1377. Buck Doe, Petitioner v. Elaine L. Chao, Secretary of
Labor. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Souter.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Ginsburg, with whom Justice Stevens
and Justice Breyer join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Breyer.
  No. 02–811. Jeff Groh, Petitioner v. Joseph R. Ramirez, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Kennedy, with whom The Chief Justice joins. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Thomas with whom Justice Scalia joins, and
with whom The Chief Justice joins as to Part III.

JNL03$0301—03-11-04 17:04:42     JOURNAPGT         MILES




(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, MARCH 1, 2004                    623
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg and Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 02–10703. Abraham M. Forish, Petitioner v. Massachusetts. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Appeals Court of Massachusetts.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case re-
manded to the Appeals Court of Massachusetts further consideration
in light of Groh v. Ramirez, 540 U. S. ––– (2004).

                     Orders in Pending Cases
  No. 03M48. Angel Maturino Resendiz, Petitioner v. Texas. Motion
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indi-
gency executed by petitioner granted.
  No. 8, Original. State of Arizona, Complainant v. State of California,
et al. Memorandum Opinion and Order on Motions for Summary Judg-
ment and Motion in Limine received and ordered filed.
  No. 03–221. Cheryl K. Pliler, Warden, Petitioner v. Richard Herman
Ford. Motion of respondent for appointment of counsel granted. Lisa
M. Bassis, Esq., of Los Angeles, California, is appointed to serve as
counsel for the respondent in this case.
  No. 03–475. Richard B. Cheney, Vice President of the United States,
et al., Petitioners v. United States District Court for the District of
Columbia, et al. In accordance with its historic practice, the Court re-
fers the motion to recuse in this case to Justice Scalia.
  No. 03–7564. Michael Turner White, Petitioner v. Winters Mack,

                               Opinions
   No. 02–964. George H. Baldwin, Petitioner v. Michael Reese. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed. Opinion by Justice Breyer. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Stevens.
   No. 02–458. Raymond B. Yates, M.D., P.C. Profit Sharing Plan, and
Raymond B. Yates, Trustee, Petitioners v. William T. Hendon, Trustee.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court, including consideration of
questions earlier raised but not resolved. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg.
Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Jus-
tice Thomas concurring in the judgment.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice O’Connor, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                      Orders in Pending Cases
   No. 03M49. Under Seal, Petitioner v. United States. Motion for leave
to file a petition for writ of certiorari under seal with redacted copies
for the public record granted.
   No. 8, Original. State of Arizona, Complainant v. State of California,
et al. Motion of Billy Wayne Andrews, Jr., for leave to intervene denied.
   No. 02–572. Intel Corporation, Petitioner v. Advanced Micro De-
vices, Inc. Motion of Commission of the European Communities for
leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided
argument granted. Motion of the Solicitor General for leave to partici-
pate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument
granted. Justice O’Connor took no part in the consideration or decision
of these motions.
   No. 02–1609. City of Littleton, Colorado, Petitioner v. Z.J. Gifts D-4,
L.L.C., a Limited Liability Company, dba Christal’s. Motion of peti-
tioner for divided argument denied. Motion of Ohio, et al., for leave to
participate in oral argument as amici curiae and for divided argu-
ment granted.
   No. 03–932. Dura Pharmaceuticals, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Michael
Broudo, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case
expressing the views of the United States.
   No. 03–8150. John Bielenberg, et ux., Petitioners v. David Griffiths,
et al. Motion of petitioners for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
denied. Petitioners allowed until March 29, 2004, within which to pay
the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33.1 of the Rules of this Court.
   No. 03–8253. Stephan A. Bitterman, Petitioner v. Nancy Little Hoff-
man, et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
denied. Petitioner allowed until March 29, 2004, within which to pay
the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33.1 of the Rules of this Court.

Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

  No. 03–9271. David J. Brown, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. Application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Breyer
and by him referred to the Court denied. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma denied. Justice Scalia
took no part in the consideration or decision of this application and
this petition.

(JOURNAL)                  FRIDAY, MARCH 19, 2004                     679
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg and Justice Breyer.

                      Orders in Pending Cases
   No. 02–1624. Elk Grove Unified School District and David W. Gor-
don, Superintendent, Petitioners v. Michael A. Newdow, et al. Motion
of Institute in Basic Life Principles, Faith and Action, et al., for recon-
sideration of order denying their motion for leave to participate in oral
argument as amici curiae and for divided argument denied. Justice
Scalia took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
   No. 03–95. Pennsylvania State Police, Petitioner v. Nancy Drew Sud-
ers. Motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral
argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument granted. Motion
of respondent and amicus curiae Lawyers’ Committee for Civil Rights
Under Law for leave to allow Lawyers’ Committee for Civil Rights
Under Law to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for
divided argument denied.
   No. 03–339. Jose Francisco Sosa, Petitioner v. Humberto Alvarez-
Machain, et al.; and
   No. 03–485. United States, Petitioner v. Humberto Alvarez-Machain,
et al. Motion of the Solicitor General for enlargement of time for oral
argument and for divided argument granted.


                       Order in Pending Case
  No. 03A797. Jon Ozmint, Director, South Carolina Department of
Corrections, et al., Applicants v. David C. Hill. Application to vacate
preliminary injunction of execution of sentence of death entered by the
United States District Court for the District of South Carolina on
March 4, 2004, presented to The Chief Justice and by him referred to
the Court granted. Justice Stevens, Justice Souter, Justice Ginsburg,
and Justice Breyer would deny the application to vacate the prelimi-
nary injunction of execution.
JNL03$0322—03-31-04 19:44:09       JOURNAPGT           MILES




(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, MARCH 22, 2004                        681
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES


  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg and Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                    Certiorari—Summary Dispositions
  No. 03–7276. Remon Shields, Petitioner v. California. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate
District. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate Dis-
trict, for further consideration in light of Crawford v. Washington, 541
U. S. ––– (2004).
  No. 03–7626. Sergio Corona, Petitioner v. Florida. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fifth
District. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fifth District,
for further consideration in light of Crawford v. Washington, 541 U. S.
––– (2004).
                       Orders in Pending Cases
   No. 03A616. Kim Moss, Applicant v. Gerald Hofbauer, Warden. Ap-
plication for a certificate of appealability addressed to Justice Ginsburg
and referred to the Court denied.
   No. 03M51. Flem Calhoun, II, Petitioner v. Frisco Railroad, et al.
Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-
time denied.

   No. 03–8376. Ivo Nabelek, Petitioner v. Texas. Motion of petitioner
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of
certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas dismissed. See
Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s process,
the Clerk is directed not to accept any further petitions in noncriminal
matters from petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a)
is paid and petition submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin
v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per cu-
riam). Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.
   No. 03–8381. Ivo Nabelek, Petitioner v. Texas. Motion of petitioner
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of
certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas dismissed. See
Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s process,
the Clerk is directed not to accept any further petitions in noncriminal
matters from petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a)
JNL03$0322—03-31-04 19:44:09    JOURNAPGT          MILES

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg and Justice Breyer.

                                Opinions
   No. 02–1389. United States, Petitioner v. Abel Cosmo Galletti, et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Thomas.
   No. 02–626. South Florida Water Management District, Petitioner
v. Miccosukee Tribe of Indians, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice O’Connor. Opinion by Justice Scalia,
concurring in part and dissenting in part.

States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by The Chief
Justice. Concurring opinion by Justice Breyer.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   No. 02–1593. BedRoc Limited, LLC, and Western Elite, Inc., Peti-
tioners v. United States, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. The Chief Justice announced the judgment of the Court and
delivered an opinion, in which Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, and
Justice Kennedy join. Opinion by Justice Thomas, with whom Justice
Breyer joins, concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens, with whom Justice Souter and Justice Ginsburg join.

(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, APRIL 5, 2004                      747
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg and Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                   Certiorari—Summary Dispositions

   No. 02–599. Sheila Foster Anthony and Lisa Foster Moody, Petition-
ers v. Allan J. Favish, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The Court re-
versed the judgment below in National Archives and Records Admin-
istration v. Favish, 541 U. S. ––– (2004). Therefore, petition for writ of
certiorari granted, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit to enter appropriate orders as may be
necessary.
   No. 02–1270. Steven E. Perlman, Petitioner v. Department of Jus-
tice. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit for further consideration in light of
National Archives and Records Administration v. Favish, 541 U. S.
––– (2004).
   No. 02–5651. Christopher S. Oguaju, Petitioner v. United States
Marshals Service. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit
for further consideration in light of National Archives and Records
Administration v. Favish, 541 U. S. ––– (2004).

                      Orders in Pending Cases

  No. 03M58. Esteban Bautista, Petitioner v. Bill Lockyer, Attorney

Maryland denied. Justice O’Connor took no part in the consideration or
decision of this petition.
   No. 03–8716. George Roger Siegel, Petitioner v. Arlington County
Department of Community Planning Housing and Development, et al.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied,
and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8.
   No. 03–8771. Danny James Cohea, Petitioner v. California. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California dismissed.
See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s proc-
ess, the Clerk is directed not to accept any further petitions in noncrim-
inal matters from petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule
38(a) is paid and petition submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See
Martin v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992)
(per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited
therein.
   No. 03–8848. Gene Enrique Aviles, Petitioner v. Colorado. Motion of
petitioner to consolidate case with No. 03–407, Kowalski v. Tesmer
denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Colo-
rado denied.
   No. 03–9057. Robert Lee Hood, Petitioner v. Steve Dotson, Warden.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied,
and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8.

                       Habeas Corpus Denied
  No. 03–9332. In Re Shaikh Shi’ite T. Al-Amin Khashoggi, fka Kip

  No. 03–9225. Coy Ray Phelps, Petitioner v. John D. Ashcroft, Attor-
ney General, et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As
petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is di-
rected not to accept any further petitions in noncriminal matters from
petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and
petition submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District
of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice
Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

802                       MONDAY, APRIL 19, 2004

                         Attorney Discipline

   No. D–2375. In the Matter of Discipline of Daniel J. Gates. Daniel J.
Gates, of Zelienople, Pennsylvania, is suspended from the practice of
law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–2376. In the Matter of Discipline of Mark Andrew Gomez.
Mark Andrew Gomez, of Newnan, Georgia, is suspended from the prac-
tice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

                            Recess Order

  The Court will take a recess from Monday, May 3, 2004, until Mon-
day, May 17, 2004.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,

  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                   Certiorari—Summary Disposition

  No. 03–910. Larry Leake, in His Official Capacity as Chairman of
the North Carolina State Board of Elections, et al., Petitioners v. North
Carolina Right to Life, Inc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further
consideration in light of McConnell v. Federal Election Comm’n, 540
U. S. ––– (2003).
                      Orders in Pending Cases

   No. 03M65. Leroy Logan, Petitioner v. Jarrett Bridgeman, et al. Mo-
tion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-
time denied.
  No. 03M66. In Re Riduoane Khalid, Petitioner. Motion for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency executed
by petitioner granted.
   No. 03M67. In Re Jamil El-Banna, Bisher Al-Rawi, Mourad Benchel-
lalli, and Murat Kurnaz, Petitioners. Motion for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency executed by peti-
tioners granted.
  No. 128, Original. State of Alaska, Plaintiff v. United States of
America. Report of the Special Master received and ordered filed. Ex-
ceptions to the Report, with supporting briefs, may be filed within
45 days. Reply briefs, if any, with supporting briefs, may be filed
within 30 days.
  No. 03–377. Koons Buick Pontiac GMC, Inc., Petitioner v. Bradley
Nigh. Motion of petitioner to dispense with printing the joint appen-
dix granted.

                          Oral Arguments
  No. 03–221. Cheryl K. Pliler, Warden, Petitioner v. Richard Herman
Ford. Argued by Mr. Paul M. Roadarmel, Jr., for the petitioner and by
Ms. Lisa M. Bassis, appointed by this Court, for the respondent.
  No. 03–724. F. Hoffmann-La Roche Ltd, et al., Petitioners v. Empa-
gran S.A., et al. Argued by Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro for the petitioners,
by Mr. R. Hewitt Pate for the United States as amicus curiae, by
special leave of the Court, and by Mr. Thomas C. Goldstein for the
respondents. Justice O’Connor recused.


  Adjourned until Tuesday, April 27, 2004, at 10 o’clock.

                               Orders
  Ordered:
  1. That the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure be, and they
hereby are, amended by including therein amendments to Bankruptcy
Rules 1011, 2002, and 9014.
  2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Bank-
ruptcy Procedure shall take effect on December 1, 2004, and shall gov-
ern in all proceedings in bankruptcy cases thereafter commenced and,
insofar as just and practicable, all proceedings then pending.
  3. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Bankruptcy Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section
2075 of Title 28, United States Code.
  Ordered:
  1. That the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure be, and they
hereby are, amended by including therein an amendment to Criminal
Rule 35.
  2. That the rules and forms governing cases in the United States
District Courts under Section 2254 and Section 2255 of Title 28, United
States Code, be, and they hereby are, amended by including therein
JNL03$0426—05-06-04 14:09:03    JOURNAPGT         MILES




                         MONDAY, APRIL 26, 2004                   835
amendments to Rules 1 through 11 of the Rules Governing Section
2254 Cases in the United States District Courts, Rules 1 through 12 of
the Rules Governing Section 2255 Cases in the United States District
Courts, and forms for use in applications under Section 2254 and mo-
tions under Section 2255.
   3. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Criminal
Procedure, the Rules Governing Section 2254 Cases in the United
States District Courts, and the Rules Governing Section 2255 Cases in
the United States District Courts shall take effect on December 1,
2004, and shall govern in all proceedings thereafter commenced and
insofar as just and practicable, all proceedings then pending.
   4. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Criminal Procedure, the Rules Governing Section 2254 Cases in the
United States District Courts, and the Rules Governing Section 2255
Cases in the United States District Courts in accordance with the pro-
visions of Section 2072 of Title 28, United States Code.

                               Opinions
   No. 02–1343. Engine Manufacturers Association and Western States
Petroleum Association, Petitioners v. South Coast Air Quality Manage-
ment District, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
proceedings consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Souter.
   No. 02–1580. Richard Vieth, Norma Jean Vieth, and Susan Furey,
Appellants v. Robert C. Jubelirer, President of the Pennsylvania Sen-
ate, et al. On appeal from the United States District Court for the
Middle District of Pennsylvania. Judgment of the District Court af-
firmed. Justice Scalia announced the judgment of the Court and deliv-
ered an opinion, in which The Chief Justice, Justice O’Connor, and Jus-
tice Thomas join. Opinion by Justice Kennedy, concurring in the
judgment. Dissenting opinion announced by Justice Stevens. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Souter, with whom Justice Ginsburg joins. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Breyer.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and
Justice Ginsburg.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                         Opinion Per Curiam
  No. 03–1028. Raymond L. Middleton, Warden, Petitioner v. Sally
Marie McNeil. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
and motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings consist-
ent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.

                      Orders in Pending Cases
  No. 03M68. Brett A. Rodman, Petitioner v. Florida. Motion to direct
the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time denied.
  No. 03M69. George Doe, Petitioner v. United States. Motion for
leave to file a petition for writ of certiorari under seal with redacted
copies for the public record granted.
  No. 03M70. Johnny A. Garcia, Petitioner v. City of Clayton, New
Mexico. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari
out-of-time denied.
  No. 03–1238. IBP, Inc., Petitioner v. Gabriel Alvarez, Individually
and on Behalf of All Others Similarly Situated, et al. The Solicitor
General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of
the United States.
  No. 03–8476. In Re Daries Sherrills, Petitioner. Motion of petitioner
for reconsideration of order denying leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris denied.

   No. 02–1657. Randall C. Scarborough, Petitioner v. Anthony J. Prin-
cipi, Secretary of Veterans Affairs. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. Judgment reversed,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fed-
eral Circuit for further proceedings consistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Thomas, with whom Justice Scalia joins.
  No. 02–1824. Doug Dretke, Director, Texas Department of Criminal
Justice, Correctional Institutions Division, Petitioner v. Michael Wayne
Haley. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further proceedings
consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O’Connor.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Kennedy and
Justice Souter join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy.
   No. 02–1205. Edith Jones, et al., on Behalf of Herself and a Class of
Others Similarly Situated, Petitioners v. R. R. Donnelley & Sons Com-
pany. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further
proceedings consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice Stevens.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,

  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                   Certiorari—Summary Dispositions
   No. 02–10386. Cecilia M. Donoghue, Petitioner v. Lynn Q. Doherty,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further consideration in light of
Jones v. R. R. Donnelley & Sons Co., 541 U. S. ––– (2004).
   No. 03–9286. Kajornsak Prasertphong, Petitioner v. Arizona. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the Supreme Court of Arizona for further consideration in light of
Crawford v. Washington, 541 U. S. ––– (2004).

                           MONDAY, MAY 17, 2004                     883
   No. 03–9617. Anant Kumar Tripati, Petitioner v. Dora B. Schriro,
Director, Arizona Department of Corrections, et al. Motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly abused
this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any further
petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the docketing
fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in compliance
with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals,
506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4,
and cases cited therein.
   No. 03–9728. Morris J. Perry, Sr., Petitioner v. United States. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly
abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any
further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

                               Opinions
   No. 03–44. Basim Omar Sabri, Petitioner v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for proceedings consistent with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter. Opinion by Justice
Kennedy, with whom Justice Scalia joins, concurring in part. Opinion
by Justice Thomas concurring in the judgment.
   No. 02–1689. Grupo Dataflux, Petitioner v. Atlas Global Group, L. P.,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Ginsburg, with whom Justice Stevens, Jus-
tice Souter, and Justice Breyer join.
   No. 02–1016. Lee M. Till, et ux., Petitioners v. SCS Credit Corpora-
tion. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit with instruc-
tions to remand the case to the Bankruptcy Court for further proceed-
ings consistent with the opinion of this Court. Justice Stevens an-
JNL03$0517—06-03-04 12:08:35    JOURNAPGT         MILES




                          MONDAY, MAY 17, 2004                     889
nounced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion, in which
Justice Souter, Justice Ginsburg and Justice Breyer join. Opinion by
Justice Thomas concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Scalia, with whom The Chief Justice, Justice O’Connor, and Justice
Kennedy join.
  No. 02–1667. Tennessee, Petitioner v. George Lane, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Concurring opinion by
Justice Souter, with whom Justice Ginsburg joins. Concurring opinion
by Justice Ginsburg, with whom Justice Souter and Justice Breyer join.
Dissenting opinion by The Chief Justice, with whom Justice Kennedy
and Justice Thomas join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Thomas.
   No. 02–1606. Tennessee Student Assistance Corporation, Petitioner
v. Pamela L. Hood. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed, and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further
proceedings consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by The
Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by Justice Souter, with whom Justice
Ginsburg joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas, with whom Jus-
tice Scalia joins.

tor, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Correctional Institutions

JNL03$0524—06-04-04 11:29:03     JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, MAY 24, 2004                      899
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                   Certiorari—Summary Dispositions

   No. 03–279. Columbia River Correctional Institute, et al., Petition-
ers v. Billy Ray Phiffer. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration
in light of Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U. S. ––– (2004).
   No. 03–533. Lori Ann Parr, Petitioner v. Middle Tennessee State
University, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U. S. ––– (2004).
   No. 03–534. Elizabeth Feaster, Petitioner v. Florida Department of
Health, Board of Nursing. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Dis-
trict Court of Appeal of Florida, First District. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the Dis-
trict Court of Appeal of Florida, First District, for further consider-
ation in light of Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U. S. ––– (2004).
  No. 03–559. Sergio Rendon, et al., Petitioners v. Florida Department
of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles, et al. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District, for
further consideration in light of Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U. S. ––– (2004).
  No. 03–6536. Micheal Lee Spencer, Sr., Petitioner v. Belinda Easter,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
JNL03$0524—06-04-04 11:29:03      JOURNAPGT           MILES




900                         MONDAY, MAY 24, 2004

Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U. S. ––– (2004).
   No. 03–7364. Matthew Kiman, Petitioner v. New Hampshire Depart-
ment of Corrections, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U. S. ––– (2004).

                      Orders in Pending Cases

   No. 03M75. Da Lu Tung, Petitioner v. Republic National Bank, et al.
Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-
time denied.
   No. 128, Original. State of Alaska, Plaintiff v. United States of
America. Motion of the Special Master for allowance of fees and reim-
bursement granted, and the Special Master is awarded a total of
$74,376.56 for the period October 17, 2003, through April 19, 2004, to
be paid equally by the parties.
   No. 02–1192. Cooper Industries, Inc., Petitioner v. Aviall Services,
Inc. Motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral
argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument granted.
   No. 02–10038. Robert James Tennard, Petitioner v. Doug Dretke,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Correctional Institu-
tions Division. Motion of petitioner for leave to file a supplemental
brief after argument granted.
   No. 03–377. Koons Buick Pontiac GMC, Inc., Petitioner v. Bradley
Nigh. Motion of National Automobile Dealers Association for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae granted.
   No. 03–8376. Ivo Nabelek, Petitioner v. Texas. Motion of petitioner
for reconsideration of order denying leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris denied.
   No. 03–8381. Ivo Nabelek, Petitioner v. Texas. Motion of petitioner
for reconsideration of order denying leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris denied.
   No. 03–9005. Matthew D. Cuyler, Petitioner v. Wal-Mart Stores. Mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied. Peti-
tioner allowed until June 14, 2004, within which to pay the docketing
fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with
JNL03$0524—10-07-04 15:00:45     JOURNAPGT          MILES




                           MONDAY, MAY 24, 2004                     901
Rule 33.1 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Breyer took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion.
                        Certiorari Granted
   No. 03–1039. Jill L. Brown, Acting Warden, Petitioner v. William
Charles Payton. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
   No. 03–1116. Jennifer M. Granholm, Governor of Michigan, et al.,
Petitioners v. Eleanor Heald, et al.;
   No. 03–1120. Michigan Beer & Wine Wholesalers Association, Peti-
tioner v. Eleanor Heald, et al. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted; and
   No. 03–1274. Juanita Swedenburg, et al., Petitioners v. Edward D.
Kelly, Chairman, New York Division of Alcoholic Beverage Control,
State Liquor Authority, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit granted limited
to the following Question: “Does a State’s regulatory scheme that per-
mits in-state wineries directly to ship alcohol to consumers but re-
stricts the ability of out-of-state wineries to do so violate the dormant
Commerce Clause in light of Sec. 2 of the 21st Amendment?” These
cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral
argument.
   No. 03–1164. Ann M. Veneman, Secretary of Agriculture, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Livestock Marketing Association, et al.; and
   No. 03–1165. Nebraska Cattlemen, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Live-
stock Marketing Association, et al. Motion of 48 Cattle and Agricul-
tural Associations for leave to file a brief as amici curiae in
No. 03–1164 granted. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit granted limited to Ques-
tion 1 presented by each petition. These cases are consolidated and a
total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.

                                 Opinions

  No. 03–6821. David L. Nelson, Petitioner v. Donal Campbell, Com-
missioner, Alabama Department of Corrections, et al. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit.
Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further proceedings consistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O’Connor.
  No. 03–5165. Marcus Thornton, Petitioner v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by The Chief Justice, except as to
footnote 4. Opinion by Justice O’Connor, concurring in part. Opinion
by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice Ginsburg joins, concurring in the
judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice
Souter joins.
