JNL03$0601—06-15-04 09:55:22      JOURNAPGT           MILES




(JOURNAL)                   TUESDAY, JUNE 1, 2004                      917
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, and
Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                         Orders in Pending Cases
  No. 03M76. Kelly Hughes, et vir, Petitioners v. Price Company, et al.
Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-
time denied.
  No. 105, Original. Kansas, Plaintiff v. Colorado. Motion of Kansas
for leave to file a sur-reply granted. Exceptions to the Report of the
Special Master are set for oral argument in due course.

                          Certiorari Denied
  No. 03–1073. H. C. Bailey, Jr., et al., Petitioners v. United States,
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Federal Circuit denied.
  No. 03–1088. Scott Rise, Petitioner v. United States. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit denied.
  No. 03–1135. Ferrer, Poirot & Wansbrough and Steven Mestem-
acher, Petitioners v. Bombardier Aerospace Employee Welfare Benefits
Plan. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
  No. 03–1211. John MacLachlan, James Brown, Stephen K. Manley,
Alaina Spurlock, Bernd Stahr, and Michael Zaiontz, Petitioners v.
ExxonMobil Corporation, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
  No. 03–1212. Rosemarie Clampitt, Petitioner v. Starving Students,

   No. 03–836. Colorado, Petitioner v. Wade Miller. Motion of respond-

of California, Second Appellate District, denied.
   No. 03–9564. James E. Flynn, Jr., Petitioner v. Patrick T. Murphy.

and petition for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois,
First District, dismissed. See Rule 39.8.
   No. 03–9858. Joseph Dixon, Petitioner v. EquiCredit Corporation,
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eighth Circuit denied. Justice Breyer took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.

(JOURNAL)                   MONDAY, JUNE 7, 2004                       941
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “The Court notes with sadness the death of former President Ronald
Reagan last Saturday. When the Court recesses today, it will do so in
respect for his memory.
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                    Certiorari—Summary Disposition

   No. 03–9708. John T. Goff, Petitioner v. Ohio. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Summit County. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals of Ohio, Summit County, for further consideration in
light of Crawford v. Washington, 541 U. S. ––– (2004).

                      Orders in Pending Cases

  No. 03M77. Michael Palumbo, Petitioner v. Jill A. Brown, Warden.
Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-
time denied.
  No. 03M78. Roger W. Knight, Petitioner v. Fred Stephens, Director,
Washington State Department of Licensing, et al. Motion of petitioner
to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time
denied.
  No. 03–1230. American Trucking Associations, Inc. and USF Hol-
land, Inc., Petitioners v. Michigan Public Service Commission, et al.;
  No. 03–1234. Mid-Con Freight Systems, Inc., et al., Petitioners v.
Michigan Public Service Commission, et al.; and
  No. 03–1250. Troy Cab, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Michigan Public
Service Commission, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a
brief in these cases expressing the views of the United States.
  No. 03–7434. Daniel Benitez, Petitioner v. John Mata, Interim Field
Office Director, Miami Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforce-
ment. Motion of petitioner for appointment of counsel granted. John S.
JNL03$0607—06-17-04 20:47:47     JOURNAPGT          MILES




942                        MONDAY, JUNE 7, 2004

Mills, Esquire, of Jacksonville, Florida, is appointed to serve as counsel
for the petitioner in this case.
  No. 03–9011. Bill A. Corbin, Petitioner v. Florida Bar. Motion of
petitioner for reconsideration of order denying leave to proceed
in forma pauperis denied.
  No. 03–9675. Edward Strange, Jr., Petitioner v. Norfolk Southern
Corporation. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris denied. Petitioner allowed until June 28, 2004, within which to
pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition
in compliance with Rule 33.1 of the Rules of this Court.
  No. 03–10067. Gary J. Holland, Petitioner v. Jo Anne B. Barnhart,
Commissioner of Social Security. Motion of petitioner for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis denied. Petitioner allowed until June 28, 2004,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to
submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33.1 of the Rules of this
Court.
                         Certiorari Granted
  No. 03–1407. Richard Gerald Rousey, et ux., Petitioners v. Jill R.
Jacoway. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit granted.

   No. 03–10311. In Re Jerry L. Wilson, Petitioner;

JNL03$0607—06-17-04 20:47:47     JOURNAPGT          MILES




952                        MONDAY, JUNE 7, 2004

writ of habeas corpus dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has re-
peatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept
any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

                         Mandamus Denied

  No. 03–9623. In Re Daniel John Sheehan, Petitioner; and
  No. 03–9654. In Re Abraham Cruz, Petitioner. Petitions for writs of
mandamus denied.
  No. 03–9619. In Re Purcell Bronson, Petitioner. Motion of petitioner
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of
mandamus and/or prohibition dismissed. See Rule 39.8.

                              Opinions
   No. 02–1609. City of Littleton, Colorado, Petitioner v. Z. J. Gifts
D–4, L.L.C., a Limited Liability Company, dba Christal’s. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit.
Judgment reversed. Opinion by Justice Breyer. Opinion by Justice Ste-
vens concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by
Justice Souter, with whom Justice Kennedy joins, concurring in part
and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Scalia, concurring
in the judgment.
   No. 03–358. Department of Transportation, et al., Petitioners v. Pub-
lic Citizen, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded
JNL03$0607—06-17-04 20:47:47    JOURNAPGT         MILES




956                       MONDAY, JUNE 7, 2004

to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
proceedings consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice Thomas.
   No. 02–891. Central Laborers’ Pension Fund, Petitioner v. Thomas
E. Heinz, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Souter. Concurring opinion by Justice Breyer, with whom The Chief
Justice, Justice O’Connor, and Justice Ginsburg join.
   No. 03–13. Republic of Austria, et al., Petitioners v. Maria V. Alt-
mann. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia. Concurring opinion by Justice
Breyer, with whom Justice Souter joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Kennedy, with whom The Chief Justice and Justice Thomas join.

(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, JUNE 14, 2004                     963
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                   Certiorari—Summary Dispositions

   No. 03–284. Societe Nationale des Chemins de Fer Francais, Peti-
tioner v. Raymond Abrams, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further
consideration in light of Republic of Austria v. Altmann, 541 U. S.
––– (2004).
  No. 03–500. Republic of Austria and Osterreichische Industriehold-
ing AG, Petitioners v. Dorit Whiteman, et al.; and
  No. 03–517. Republic of Poland, et al., Petitioners v. Theo Garb, et al.
On petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Second Circuit. Petitions for writs of certiorari granted.
Judgments vacated, and cases remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit for further consideration in light of
Republic of Austria v. Altmann, 541 U. S. ––– (2004).
  No. 03–741. Hwang Geum Joo, et al., Petitioners v. Japan. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit for further consideration
in light of Republic of Austria v. Altmann, 541 U. S. ––– (2004).
   No. 03–1348. Edmund Ko, Petitioner v. New York. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New
York, First Judicial Department. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the Appellate Division, Su-
preme Court of New York, First Judicial Department, for further con-
sideration in light of Crawford v. Washington, 541 U. S. ––– (2004).

                       Habeas Corpus Denied
  No. 03–10442. In Re David Carroll, Petitioner;
  No. 03–10508. In Re Kevin P. Miller, Petitioner; and
  No. 03–10510. In Re Eric J. Rhett, Petitioner. Petitions for writs of
habeas corpus denied.
  No. 03–10478. In Re Darrell Lamont Bailey, Petitioner. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition
for writ of habeas corpus dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has
repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to
accept any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner
unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition
submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Co-
lumbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Ste-
vens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

                          Mandamus Denied
   No. 03–9751. In Re Daniel Albert Bellon, Petitioner. Petition for
writ of mandamus and/or prohibition denied.
   No. 03–10175. In Re Arthur Morrison, Petitioner. Motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for
JNL03$0614—07-02-04 19:31:10     JOURNAPGT         MILES




                          MONDAY, JUNE 14, 2004                    979
writ of mandamus dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeat-
edly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept
any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

                                 Opinions
  No. 03–724. F. Hoffmann-La Roche Ltd, et al., Petitioners v. Empa-
gran S. A., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
JNL03$0614—07-02-04 19:31:10      JOURNAPGT         MILES




982                        MONDAY, JUNE 14, 2004

Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment vacated, and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit for further proceedings consistent with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Breyer. Opinion by Justice Scalia,
with whom Justice Thomas joins, concurring in the judgment. Justice
O’Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
   No. 02–1809. J. Elliott Hibbs, Director, Arizona Department of Rev-
enue, Petitioner v. Kathleen M. Winn, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg. Concurring opinion by Justice
Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy, with whom The Chief
Justice, Justice Scalia, and Justice Thomas join.
  No. 03–95. Pennsylvania State Police, Petitioner v. Nancy Drew Sud-
ers. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further proceedings
consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas.
  No. 03–167. United States, Petitioner v. Carlos Dominguez Benitez.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings
consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter.
Opinion by Justice Scalia, concurring in the judgment.
   No. 02–1624. Elk Grove Unified School District and David W. Gor-
don, Superintendent, Petitioners v. Michael A. Newdow, et al. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by The
Chief Justice, with whom Justice O’Connor joins, and with whom Jus-
tice Thomas joins as to Part I, concurring in the judgment. Opinion by
Justice O’Connor, concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice
Thomas, concurring in the judgment. Justice Scalia took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
   No. 03–101. Gale Norton, Secretary of the Interior, et al., Petitioners
v. Southern Utah Wilderness Alliance, et al. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment
reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Tenth Circuit for further proceedings consistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia, announced by The Chief Justice.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                      Order in Pending Case
   No. 03A1023. Frank C. Sizer, Jr., Commissioner, Maryland Depart-
ment of Corrections, et al., Applicants v. Steven Howard Oken. Applica-
tion to vacate the stay of execution of sentence of death entered by the
United States District Court for the District of Maryland on June 14,
2004, presented to The Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court
granted. Justice Stevens, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer would
deny the application to vacate the stay of execution.


                         Certiorari Denied
  No. 03–10808. Steven Howard Oken, Petitioner v. Maryland. Appli-
cation for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to The Chief
Justice and by him referred to the Court denied. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Maryland denied.

JNL03$0621—07-07-04 14:49:20      JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, JUNE 21, 2004                      991
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and
Justice Ginsburg.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                   Certiorari—Summary Dispositions

   No. 02–1703. Utah Shared Access Alliance, et al., Petitioners v.
Southern Utah Wilderness Alliance, et al. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. The
Court reversed the judgment below in Norton v. Southern Utah Wil-
derness Alliance, 542 U. S. ––– (2004). Therefore, petition for writ of
certiorari granted, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further proceedings.
   No. 03–109. Ann M. Veneman, Secretary of Agriculture, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Montana Wilderness Association, Inc., et al.; and
   No. 03–123. Blue Ribbon Coalition, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Mon-
tana Wilderness Association, Inc., et al. On petitions for writs of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Peti-
tions for writs of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and cases
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Norton v. Southern Utah Wilder-
ness Alliance, 542 U. S. ––– (2004).
   No. 03–1015. Bank Austria AG, et al., Petitioners v. John L.
Sniado, III, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further consideration in
light of F. Hoffman-La Roche v. Empagran S.A., 542 U. S. ––– (2004).

                        Orders in Pending Cases

   No. 03M80. Heriberto C., Petitioner v. Los Angeles County Depart-
ment of Children and Family Services. Motion for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency executed by peti-
tioner denied.

                               Opinions

  No. 02–572. Intel Corporation, Petitioner v. Advanced Micro
Devices, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Ginsburg. Opinion by Justice Scalia, concurring in the judgment. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Breyer. Justice O’Connor took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
   No. 02–1845. Aetna Health Inc., fka Aetna U. S. Healthcare Inc. and
Aetna U. S. Healthcare of North Texas Inc., Petitioner v. Juan Davila;
and
   No. 03–83. CIGNA HealthCare of Texas, Inc., dba CIGNA Corpora-
tion, Petitioner v. Ruby R. Calad, et al. On writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed, and cases remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit for further proceedings consistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice Thomas. Concurring opinion by Justice
Ginsburg, with whom Justice Breyer joins.
  No. 03–221. Cheryl K. Pliler, Warden, Petitioner v. Richard Herman
Ford. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings
JNL03$0621—07-07-04 14:49:20      JOURNAPGT         MILES




                           MONDAY, JUNE 21, 2004                 1011
consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Thomas.
Concurring opinion by Justice O’Connor. Opinion by Justice Stevens,
with whom Justice Souter joins, concurring in the judgment. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Ginsburg, with whom Justice Breyer joins. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Breyer.
   No. 03–5554. Larry D. Hiibel, Petitioner v. Sixth Judicial District
Court of Nevada, Humboldt County, et al. On writ of certiorari to Su-
preme Court of Nevada. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Ken-
nedy. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Breyer, with whom Justice Souter and Justice Ginsburg join.

(JOURNAL)                 THURSDAY, JUNE 24, 2004                   1017
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg and Justice Breyer.

                                Opinions
   No. 02–1603. Jeffrey A. Beard, Secretary, Pennsylvania Department
of Corrections, et al., Petitioners v. George E. Banks. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Third Circuit for further proceedings consistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Thomas. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Souter, Justice Ginsburg, and
Justice Breyer join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Souter, with whom
Justice Ginsburg joins.
   No. 03–475. Richard B. Cheney, Vice President of the United States,
et al., Petitioners v. United States District Court for the District of
Columbia, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment vacated, and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit for further proceedings consistent with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Concurring opinion by Jus-
tice Stevens. Opinion by Justice Thomas, with whom Justice Scalia
joins, concurring in part and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion an-
nounced by Justice Ginsburg, with whom Justice Souter joins.
   No. 02–1632. Ralph Howard Blakely, Jr., Petitioner v. Washington.
On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Washington, Division
3. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals of
Washington, Division 3, for further proceedings not inconsistent with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion
announced by Justice O’Connor, with whom Justice Breyer joins, and
with whom The Chief Justice and Justice Kennedy join as to all but
Part IV-B. Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy, with whom Justice
Breyer joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Breyer, with whom Justice
O’Connor joins.
   No. 03–526. Dora B. Schriro, Director, Arizona Department of Cor-
rections, Petitioner v. Warren Wesley Summerlin. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment
JNL03$0624—06-29-04 20:10:52     JOURNAPGT         MILES




1018                     THURSDAY, JUNE 24, 2004

reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings consistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Breyer, with whom Justice Stevens, Justice Souter, and Justice Gins-
burg join.
   No. 02–10038. Robert James Tennard, Petitioner v. Doug Dretke,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Correctional Institu-
tions Division. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further
proceedings consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice O’Connor. Dissenting opinion by The Chief Justice. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas.


  Adjourned until Monday, June 28, 2004, at 10 o’clock.

(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, JUNE 28, 2004                   1019
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                          Opinion Per Curiam
  No. 03–1200. Flora Holland, Warden, Petitioner v. Jessie L. Jackson.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further proceedings consistent with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Justice Stevens, Justice
Souter, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer would deny the petition
for writ of certiorari.

                Certiorari—Summary Dispositions
   No. 03–69. Vytra Healthcare and Brent Spears, Petitioners v. Bonnie
Cicio, Individually and as Administratrix of the Estate of Carmine
Cicio. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit for further consideration in light of
Aetna Health Inc. v. Davila, 542 U. S. ––– (2004).
   No. 03–357. Derral G. Adams, Warden, et al., Petitioners v. Michael
D. Brambles. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in
light of Pliler v. Ford, 542 U. S. ––– (2004).
   No. 03–520. Cheryl K. Pliler, Warden, Petitioner v. Joseph Hunt. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
JNL03$0628—07-12-04 07:14:41      JOURNAPGT          MILES




1020                       MONDAY, JUNE 28, 2004

the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Pliler v. Ford,
542 U. S. ––– (2004).
   No. 03–649. CIGNA HealthCare of Florida, Petitioner v. Robbie Lee
Land, et ux. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Petition for writ of certio-
rari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consider-
ation in light of Aetna Health Inc. v. Davila, 542 U. S. ––– (2004).
   No. 03–8659. Billy Ray Nelson, Petitioner v. Doug Dretke, Director,
Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Correctional Institutions Divi-
sion. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Tennard
v. Dretke, 542 U. S. ––– (2004).
   No. 03–9412. Randy Everett Dilts, Petitioner v. Oregon. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Oregon. Motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the Su-
preme Court of Oregon for further consideration in light of Blakely v.
Washington, 542 U. S. ––– (2004).

                               Opinions

   No. 02–1183. United States, Petitioner v. Samuel Francis Patane. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth
Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further proceedings consist-
ent with the opinion of this Court. Justice Thomas announced the judg-
ment of the Court and delivered an opinion, in which The Chief Justice
and Justice Scalia join. Opinion by Justice Kennedy, with whom Justice
O’Connor joins, concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Souter, with whom Justice Stevens and Justice Ginsburg join.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Breyer.
   No. 02–1371. Missouri, Petitioner v. Patrice Seibert. On writ of cer-
tiorari to Supreme Court of Missouri. Judgment affirmed. Justice Sou-
ter announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion,
JNL03$0628—07-12-04 07:14:41     JOURNAPGT          MILES




1036                      MONDAY, JUNE 28, 2004

in which Justice Stevens, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer join.
Concurring opinion by Justice Breyer. Opinion by Justice Kennedy,
concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice O’Connor,
with whom The Chief Justice, Justice Scalia, and Justice Thomas join.
   No. 03–6696. Yaser Esam Hamdi and Esam Fouad Hamdi, as Next
Friend of Yaser Esam Hamdi, Petitioners v. Donald H. Rumsfeld, Sec-
retary of Defense, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded. Justice O’Connor announced the judgment of the Court and
delivered an opinion, in which The Chief Justice, Justice Kennedy, and
Justice Breyer join. Opinion announced by Justice Souter, with whom
Justice Ginsburg joins, concurring in part, dissenting in part, and con-
curring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion announced by Justice
Scalia, with whom Justice Stevens joins. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Thomas.
   No. 03–334. Shafiq Rasul, et al., Petitioners v. George W. Bush, Pres-
ident of the United States, et al.; and
   No. 03–343. Fawzi Khalid Abdullah Fahad Al Odah, et al., Petition-
ers v. United States, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment re-
versed, and case remanded to the United States District Court for
the District of Columbia to consider in the first instance the merits
of petitioners’ claims. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by Justice
Kennedy, concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Scalia, with whom The Chief Justice and Justice Thomas join.
   No. 03–1027. Donald H. Rumsfeld, Secretary of Defense, Petitioner
v. Jose Padilla and Donna R. Newman, as Next Friend of Jose Padilla.
On writ of certiorari to United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for entry of an order of dis-
missal without prejudice. Opinion by The Chief Justice. Concurring
opinion by Justice Kennedy, with whom Justice O’Connor joins. Dis-
senting opinion announced by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Sou-
ter, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer join. The Chief Justice said:
   “On tomorrow, Tuesday, June 29, 2004, the Court will announce the
remaining opinions ready during this Term of the Court.”


  Adjourned until Tuesday, June 29, 2004, at 10 o’clock.
JNL03$0629—07-13-04 16:38:20     JOURNAPGT         MILES




(JOURNAL)                 TUESDAY, JUNE 29, 2004                  1037
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
                               Opinions
   No. 03–339. Jose Francisco Sosa, Petitioner v. Humberto Alvarez-
Machain, et al.; and
   No. 03–485. United States, Petitioner v. Humberto Alvarez-Machain,
et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed. Opinion by Justice Souter. Opin-
ion by Justice Scalia, with whom The Chief Justice and Justice Thomas
join, concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by
Justice Ginsburg, with whom Justice Breyer joins, concurring in part
and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Breyer, concurring
in part and concurring in the judgment.
   No. 03–218. John D. Ashcroft, Attorney General, Petitioner v. Amer-
ican Civil Liberties Union, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed, and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit for further proceedings consistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Concurring opinion by Justice Ste-
vens, with whom Justice Ginsburg joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Breyer, with whom The Chief
Justice and Justice O’Connor join.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “The Court at this time wishes to note for the record that Theodore
Olson has been serving as the Solicitor General since June 11, 2001.
The Court recognizes the significant responsibilities that were placed
on him to represent the government of the United States before this
Court and to perform other important functions during difficult times.
On behalf of my colleagues, I thank you General Olson for a job well
done. You have our sincere appreciation and best wishes for the future.
   “I am authorized to announce that the Court has acted on all cases
submitted for decision this Term. Disposition of items scheduled for
Conference will be reflected on the Order List that will be released at
10 o’clock tomorrow. Accordingly, it is ordered that those cases remain-
ing on the docket, but not ready for consideration, are continued to the
session of the Court beginning October 4, 2004.
JNL03$0629—07-13-04 16:38:20      JOURNAPGT          MILES




1038                       TUESDAY, JUNE 29, 2004

  “The Court will be in recess from today until the first Monday in
October, 2004, at which time the October 2003 Term of the Court will
be adjourned and the October 2004 Term of the Court will begin as
provided by law.
  “On behalf of the Court, I thank all Supreme Court employees for
their outstanding work and their dedication to duty during this Term.
The Court, the Bar, and the public recognizes the hard work, commit-
ment, and professionalism of the Court staff. The work by the Court
staff contributes significantly to the accomplishment of the Court’s
mission.


  Adjourned until Monday, September 27, 2004, at 10 o’clock.


                       Order in Pending Case
  No. 03–11049. Mauro M. Barraza, Petitioner v. Doug Dretke, Direc-
tor, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Correctional Institutions
Division. Application for stay of execution of sentence of death pre-
sented to Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court granted pend-
ing the disposition of the petition for writ of certiorari. Should the
petition for writ of certiorari be denied, this stay shall terminate auto-
matically. In the event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, the
stay shall terminate upon issuance of the mandate of this Court.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                        Opinion Per Curiam
  No. 03–1413. Cathy Cox, Georgia Secretary of State, Appellant v.
Sara Larios, et al. On appeal from the United States District Court
for the Northern District of Georgia. Judgment affirmed. Opinion per
curiam. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice
Breyer joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia.

                Certiorari—Summary Dispositions
  No. 03–590. Wisconsin, Petitioner v. Matthew J. Knapp. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the Supreme Court of Wisconsin for further consideration in light of
United States v. Patane, 542 U. S. ––– (2004).
  No. 03–1245. George W. Bush, President of the United States, et al.,
Petitioners v. Falen Gherebi. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of re-
spondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Rumsfeld v. Padilla, 542 U. S. ––– (2004).

                        Certiorari Granted

   No. 04–104. United States, Petitioner v. Freddie J. Booker; and
   No. 04–105. United States, Petitioner v. Ducan Fanfan. Motion of
the Acting Solicitor General for leave to file a reply brief in excess of
the page limits granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit granted, and petition
for writ of certiorari before judgment to the United States Court of
Appeals for the First Circuit granted. Cases are consolidated, and a
total of two hours is allotted for oral argument. Brief of petitioner is
to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or
before 3 p.m., Wednesday, September 1, 2004. Briefs of respondents are
to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or
before 3 p.m., Tuesday, September 21, 2004. Reply brief, if any, is to be
filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before
3 p.m., Monday, September 27, 2004. Oral argument is set for Monday,
October 4, 2004.

(JOURNAL)              FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 2004                 1089
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                      Order in Pending Case
   No. 02–1028. Norfolk Southern Railway Company, Petitioner v.
James N. Kirby, Pty Ltd., dba Kirby Engineering, and Allianz Austra-
lia Limited. Parties are directed to file supplemental briefs addressing
the following question: “Does federal or state substantive law govern
the questions presented?” The Acting Solicitor General is invited to
file an amicus brief on the same question. Briefs are to be filed with
the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Mon-
day, October 4, 2004. Twenty copies of the briefs prepared under Rule
33.2 may be filed initially in order to meet the October 4 filing date.
Forty copies of the briefs prepared under Rule 33.1 are to be filed as
soon as possible thereafter.
